reviewText:
This game is one of the strangest mmo's I've ever played. Not because it’s innovative in any mind-boggling way, but because it almost seems to take active measures in order to annoy you, the player, to a point of insanity. It's the small things, like the relentless gnat that just won't die no matter how much you swat at it. Requiem has perfected the fine art of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game design. I played this game back in 2009, and it was horrible then as well. But I forgave it. “Work in progress” I thought. Well, nothing happened. The horrible programming, dull graphics, crappy hit detection, lag and unapologetic greed which constitutes this game hasn’t changed at all. Here are some examples of what Requiem has in store for you:

1.Terrible unresponsiveness in the UI and pretty much everything else. Press a button and 3 sec later something might happen, or not.
Good luck getting off your mount in any acceptable amount of time. The thought of PVP in this game is laughable.

2. The programming is so lazy it’s an insult to programmers everywhere. If you’re a spell caster and try to kite a mob, they will simply register the coordinates for where you were when they first took damage and then move to that point like an idiot, even if you are several yards away by then. Oh yeah, and they will then telepathically hit you for full damage. Why? Because f**k you that’s why.

3. PvE is about as much fun as watching bathroom mold cultivate. Bosses have ridiculous amounts of HP yet they hit like toddlers. Press auto attack then go and watch a documentary or something more constructive.

4. Several skills are broken to the point that they are a waste to even invest in. The design of the skills are also made by someone who has never played an MMORPG.

5. The quests are the typical “kill X amount of Y” but are spiced, like only Requiem can- with a cost of gold in order to get the scrolls needed. I’m serious. You get a couple “free” quests with every new area but you can forget using only them as way to level up. So you go to this agent NPC sow of a shill and are demanded to pay currency for more grind quests.

6. Somewhere around lvl 30+ you run out of quests to do and are forced to go to this temple dump of a place called “blabla ruin”-something. When you are inside you need to farm mobs for about 20 lvls. No quests, nothing- just farming mobs over and over all while constantly being PK:ed since every ♥♥♥ on the server is there as well. Enjoy.

7. Still reading? Ok then. Everything costs money, even basic stuff like mounts. You get one free, but it’s excruciatingly slow and the worlds are dead and huge. You do the math. When you get close to max lvl you are forced to buy premium. You can chose not to, and dedicate you entire life on reaching max lvl. You’ll hit the cap just in time to start enjoying your pension. And, oh yeah, if you die- you lose a big chunk of exp, and are then conveniently offered to buy an item which protects your hard earned exp from being lost at death. Convenient, right? This game is so greedy that it’s just embarrassing.

8. The mobs do a full loop and at around lvl 45 you start seeing the same mobs as in the beginning of the game once more…

9: It takes forever to get new sets of gear or to even change you appearance. Each class has 3 sets of hair and faces. You look like clones of each other.

10: Glitchy and more or less impossible game to explore when it comes to environments, charging up a hill poses a very real risk of making you fall through the map. Game is terribly plagued by mob resets.

I could go on forever but you get the idea. The sad part is that this game could actually be good. If only anyone on the developing team gave even a fraction of a sh*t. They obviously don’t and miss every shot at fixing the game. I have not the faintest clue to why it is now released on steam. It’s like throwing your sick younger cousin with chronic muscle spasms onto the stage at Let’s Dance and rubbing your hands at the thought of all the money he will make you.

The lack of commitment and care for this game is blatantly obvious, which is sad since it’s a good idea but how much are we as players expected to forgive?

2/10

reviewText:
I will divide this review into categories (history, pros/cons, recommendations for playing) for those that wish to skip, or read the details. This review is in terms of a PvE perspective as I never bothered with PvP with this game.

**History**

I played this game before back in 2008 back when it was called Requiem Bloodymare. The game was relatively fun and had an active (in-game) community.  Back then the game had two starting areas (1 being Kurt village [the desert area we drop into now] and the other being a snowy relatively nice looking area to enjoy). People ended up picking Kurt village as their starting point because the locations and enemies were closer and faster to get to. There were also a lot more quests to pick up from the NPC's in these starting locations than just the pickup scrolls. The user would bounce between the two starting areas just to get to level 25 before they proceeded onto map 2.

From there, groups would form to grind for the lamenting (cry/sound) gear from the 1 dungeon to the east in Map 2. then proceed on quest tracks in the shape of the infinity symbol (∞) [starting in the center then following the path SE to NE to SW then back to NW. By this time, the user was already grinding in the dungeon slightly to the NW to get their next set armor.

Proceeding North to map 3 it was just a barren waste land where you had to follow the scrolls to know where to go.

As to the never ending bugs with quests, people would pickup the quest then ask for the X/Y coordinates to where/who to kill to fulfill the quest.

During that time I made 3 characters:
Soul Hunter -> Dominator (for minion master purposes)
Defender -> Commander (for taunts and buffs and medium tanking)
Templar -> Radiant (for healing)

After the summer of 2008, I took a break from the game due an increased work schedule and a decreased desire to grind in the game. I came back in summer 2009 when the game had (for lack of better terms) devolved into Memento. Skills that you had acquired before at earlier levels had been moved out of your reach. Having been primarily a minion master and finally unlocking the 4th summon (other than illusion) and then finding I needed to re-unlock the skills at much later levels was beyond annoying and so I moved onto my healer I had not progressed.

Areas that you used to grind for gear had been stripped bare and the rate of drops had been massively decreased. If you had obtained the set armors for these in the past, their stats were not promoted and were incompatible with the newer versions of the set items that could only be equipped at later levels. The number of people still playing the game had also significantly dropped. Starter areas had been reduced to the 1 map kurt village and had maybe 3 people at a time in them. I lasted 1.5 months (only because of gear already acquired in the previous version of the game and wanting to experience the other classes)

Come 2015 ... they added some non-sensible useless starter video. They added a weird tutorial dungeon that when you decide to walk through to the end of the dungeon it warps you to a much higher level area. I immediately used the town transport tool that was provided to me to go to Kurt village as I knew already that this was the starting location. I believe these transport maps list the towns in the order by level if memory serves me correctly. I proceeded to play the game for about 4 hours and by that time had made it to level 27, had over 1.6 Million in-game currency (courtesy of the 50k pog pickups they are providing). With the main quest they give you they seem to be trying to rush your character to the 2nd map and ignore the beginner area. Auction house is pretty devoid of armor/weapons. People in game are pretty much non-existent. Old quest bugs still exist. User-interface unimproved.


**Pros/Cons**
Pros:
1) Had a relatively enjoyable combat system
2) Decent mail/auction house
3) Decent Bank
4) Gives you a good amount of bag storage (if you do the main quest)

Cons:
1) Graphics outdated.
2) Bugs don't seem to ever have been fixed from 2008/2009.
3) Quests are still hard to navigate with/without bugs and require veteran player knowledge or wiki to progress through.
4) The user keeps spamming the 2 attack skills they get until level 30 or so.
5) I don't know if they changed this but before if you died in Possession Beast mode, your beast was destroyed and you had to get a new one by grinding or buying from the auction house.
6) To re-open the miniquest window you have to toggle one of your quests in the main quest window to re-open. There is no user-key interface for the miniquest window.
7) Monsters will generally follow you for miles outside their territory until they have been allowed to hit you once.
8) Lack of users means no dungeons, means no progression, means game is worthless.


**Recommendations for those that want to try it**
1) Get a group of friends together and plan whose going to be what type of class so that you can have a full party for dungeons ... and survive. This simply must be done first and foremost if you want to get anything out of this game post level 50 solo as there is an extremely small user base with this game already let alone within the areas of your level.
2) The game gives the new characters a 7 day exp boost / costume / mount. Whatever character your using devote yourself to this character or delete it and make it again another day if you're not intending to make full use of the exp boost/mount.
3) The starter area has pretty much turned into a 1-2 quest chain area where they go from Kurt village in the north to the South east town in the Shape of a S. Do these quests to get your bags and gear.
4) If you get the pog drop pickup ... just sell it it's worth 50k a piece.
5) Don't bother with scroll quests until Map 2 (~lev 25-30). Note that this is for exp rather than the petty reward they offer.
6) Once in Map 2 follow the the scrolls/quests in the infinity shape starting from the center going SE as explained previously in the history section. From this point on the wiki is your friend.

Me and a friend were searching for something to do one night when I spent the night at his house. We were trolling through the free to play games, when we came across this beauty. It was sadly the most interesting game we could find. 'Why not give it a go?' we thought.
I am so glad we did.
We downloaded the game on his desktop, and his laptop. We had no idea what was in store for us.
We got into the game, and made a couple of characters. We wandered around a bit, and whacked some grotesque monsters in the face. It was alright. The game passed the time, but definitely wouldn't win any awards. I don't know when it happened, but something clicked. We could not stop playing the game. For hours and hours, we did quests, and leveled up our character in the strange dark environment of this game. The game wasn't great, and was the cause of much frustration, but we did nothing but play it. That one night gave way to several days of virtually nonstop play. We met a few friends, and did everything with them. Our team was unstoppable. We had played for 33 hours in the 3 days I spent at his house. In those 3 days, we made friends, and spawned countless memories and inside jokes. We went through our adventure observing and pointing out the flaws, but not really caring. (if you want some examles of the flaws, read literally any other review.) To this day, my friend still calls me a fuggin' koont
